title: Trajectory and Mindset
text:
Tony Robbins has said:

What we can or cannot do, what we consider possible or impossible, is rarely a function of our true capability. It is more likely a function of our beliefs about who we are. Tony Robbins Quotes, Read These Famous Quotes from Tony Robbins

The book Mindset talks about ‚Äúfixed‚Äù vs ‚Äúgrowth‚Äù mindsets. My post Decisions are Like Hopping on a River Raft - decisions take you down to known endpoints.
Bring those two concepts together and on one hand there‚Äôs a trajectory - where you‚Äôre capable of going given your decisions (and mindset) and your mindset - how you perceive your circumstances.
Someone recently told me, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not what you go through but how you perceive what you‚Äôre going through that matters.‚Äù
I believe perception is powerful. Any negative situation can be reframed for a positive. This is mindset.
But the other component is also important: where your circumstances will take you if pursued every day for the next 30 years.



Are you aimed toward the valley or the mountain? Neither is better, but one is probably better to you


If you‚Äôre an extremely happy person but you don‚Äôt take action to get out of a minimum wage job, such as spend time on self improvement, you‚Äôre going to stay in your minimum wage job (nothing wrong with that, just trying to illustrate a point).
And so, to get what you want out of life you can‚Äôt just assume things will get better without any change on your part. You can 1) change your mindset or 2) change your trajectory.
I‚Äôve wondered whether at times in my career I was complacent or not, or whether I was growing doing what I was doing. That‚Äôs not a helpful question. Because if you‚Äôre too myopic you can miss that you doing your multiplication tables isn‚Äôt going to change anyone‚Äôs life, but if you can‚Äôt do multiplication you can‚Äôt be a machine learning engineer.
Most days in our work are steps. Steps towards something.
A spaceman can‚Äôt land on the moon unless they build a rocket. They won‚Äôt make a rocket unless they choose to land on the moon. And by choosing the moon they‚Äôre choosing to not open a Chinese restaurant.1
Some roles have upper bounds. Staying at that upper bound isn‚Äôt a bad thing. It‚Äôs just a thing. Other roles open up different opportunities the longer you stick around, opportunities you won‚Äôt get else where perhaps.
So if you‚Äôre feeling stuck, ask:

Where will I be if I stay with this for the next two years?
Is that directionally where I want now to head?
Is there something about my mindset I can change today to help me reframe so that I don‚Äôt miss the opportunities already around me?

HTH.

title: The Iceberg Theory - Theory of Omission
text:
Hemingway introduced through his writing style the Iceberg Theory. It was something I noticed while reading The Old Man and the Sea. You feel the depth of emotion from the ‚Äúactions and dialogue‚Äù, rather than explicit descriptions.
It‚Äôs fun to contrast that with Frank Herbert‚Äôs style which is ‚Äúlay out the environment, have dialogue, then draw conclusions in the mind‚Äù.
Both styles speak to the thought that the writing is more interesting the less you write about. They call this ‚Äúnegative space‚Äù in drawing. A sketch is interesting when the mind can fill in the gaps. As an artist, you just want to make enough dots that they can connect them themselves. This connecting process is the freedom and interest the mind craves. It doesn‚Äôt want to be coddled (The Coddling of the American Mind).
Back to the book. The Old Man and the Sea can be summarized in one sentence: a tired, old, and recently-unlucky man catches the biggest of his life and it gets eaten before he makes it home.
That‚Äôs the surface story, and it‚Äôs rather boring when thought of that way. But you just feel so much while reading it. You feel for the old man through the young boy. You feel for him as he teeters between passing out and existing. You remember the breaking points in your own life and want the man desperately to succeed. Luck, however, was not on his side.
‚ÄúTalk less. Smile more.‚Äù - Hamilton



Let their mind wander

title: Flipping the coins of life
text:
Assume you flip a coin 5 times and get heads 5 times. You‚Äôre going pretty well!
But are you?
A normal coin has 50% chance of heads. Chances of 5 heads in a row is ~3/100. It‚Äôs not nothing. But over time this will average to 50%, if you flip 10000 times.
Decisions are rarely black and whites despite how we choice to say ‚Äúthat was a bad decision‚Äù. The outcome doesn‚Äôt determine the quality of the decision.
You chose to flip a coin, and not roll a dice. You didn‚Äôt roll a 32 sided die either.
Focus on choice that maximize probability. This is the decision.

title: The Power of Party Pay by Visible
text:
Visible‚Äôs party pay madness
Visible wireless offers $25 off to users who join a party. So a user who signs up to pay $50 for unlimited data can click one button to join a party and only have to pay $25/mo from then on. Why not just offer users $25 to begin with?
It‚Äôs really confusing to me as a user - why not just give me the $25 automatically if it takes nothing to join a group? Because of gamification.


Why it works
I think their strategy is as follows:

They hope some people get brought in on marketing and never remember to activate a party pay. Let‚Äôs say this number is 20-40%. Perhaps these users fund the rest of the discounts.
Joining a party pay group for free is an easy way to make your customers win. I.e., a user gets $25 off for joining. Gimmicky, but I think it works. So a user has an immediate sense of gratification - a great way to build a strong emotional bond. ‚ÄúClick a button to get $25 off in perpetuity? Nice!‚Äù Anyone would agree this feels better than just starting off with $25.
This makes users want to share and tell others. Especially if customers feel they‚Äôve gamed the system. Who today doesn‚Äôt like a hack?

But even if (1) is wrong, and that 95% of people join a party I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôve done the math to consider how many people they need to sign up to make the money work.


The Larger Strategy
Why would Verizon cannibalize their own sales? I switched my wife out of a $70 unlimited plan on Verizon to a $25 plan on visible for the same service. Well some customers will stay with Verizon because of its prestige and the add on benefits. But users who are cutting the cord are going somewhere else, I‚Äôm thinking Verizon wants to stay ahead of the curve. It‚Äôs a race to the bottom, sure. But it doesn‚Äôt hurt to try to win the race.

title: Blogging with Obsidian and Quarto
text:
First half is my philosophy on the relationship between learning, notetaking, and blogging.

I love to learn
Writing helps me learn
Publicly writing increases my focus

Second half is how I use Obsidian and Quarto, alternatives I‚Äôve tried, and my actually flow. I detail what tools I use, how I use them.

set up relative links
Have one img folder
Use templater to manage new post templates and relative links
Use linter
Use commander for toolbar palette
dataview to find drafts
Tags to flag ideas




I‚Äôve had a blog since 2016. Started with Jekyll. Then blogdown. Tried medium in 2020 because it had a good mobile app and I was able to publish every day. Then I didn‚Äôt know how to get my posts out of there so I lost interest. Then I found quarto, which I was excited about because I have always loved Rmarkdown (things like tabs, executable code, etc.). Then I tried Substack, which I did for a few weeks but eventually gave up because 1) no mobile app to write and 2) how do I get my stuff off of there?
Seth Godin writes every day, and I love his blog and take it as an inspiration. In one post he mentions how ‚Äúsome say do a podcast, others say write on platform x or platform Y‚Äù. (Medium, Substack, etc.) He recommends: those tools always serve the 1%. If you‚Äôre the 1%, you make money. Otherwise you don‚Äôt. So you might as well own your own content.
I know two Instagram and TikTok influencers with 100k and 300k followers respectively. The 100k made $5k in 2022. The 300k TikToker still makes maybe $100/mo. They each put in 20 hours+ a week.
So I‚Äôm giving up the illusion I‚Äôll ever make money off a blog or my content. I write because I always have. I write publicly now because I found a way to do so online, from my phone.
This is how I blog daily using quarto (for the website) and Obsidian (for the editor).

Own your platform
After all the years blogging, giving up, coming back, etc, there are many things that are my personal needs.

Mobile first. I can‚Äôt write at my computer. This isn‚Äôt my job.
Footnotes: many blogging platforms don‚Äôt allow for them or handle them well. Footnotes are essential in long content.
Customizable: I need to be able to add styling how I like it. This is part of the creative process.
Tags: having and filtering by tags is nice
Portable: if I stop blogging for 9 months I need to be able to move it to the next shiny object platform. I need to own my content. I also don‚Äôt like posting on LinkedIn or Facebook directly because I see my writing as my creative work. Those platforms don‚Äôt let you save or share those links later on.

Relative links: I need to be able to link to other posts. This is part of the mental note taking journey.
Subscribe button. (Substack and Medium are built for this!)
Comments: 99% of people don‚Äôt comment, but when people reach out it feels like I did something for the world. It also makes the blog more approachable, even if nobody every posts.
Hackable/automatable: I need templates. I need code. I need to be able to automate things. (At one point I figured out how to set up automations to post straight to Instagram from GitHub actions. I‚Äôm going to bring that back!)

Substack does footnotes well, linking to notes poorly, doesn‚Äôt have a mobile editor for posts, and isn‚Äôt portable. It handles tags, subscribers, and distribution extremely well, and makes it easy to have multiple publications. But it‚Äôs got the vendor lock in.
Medium had an excellent mobile editing experience, but again - vendor lock in. And you‚Äôve gotta kinda buy into the Medium-way-of-doing-posts.
All platforms have their vibe. If you want to be popular on TikTok, you gotta dance. Although I personally love to dance, I want my site to be creative and my own.


Why blog with obsidian/quarto?
Enter Obsidian and Quarto. Obsidian makes managing and editing content a breeze (things like draft management, sorting files, organizing images, etc is all super easy):
Why obsidian as my editor?

It makes writing markdown a breeze
It has tons of extensions, such as managing footnotes, linting files, spell checking, etc.
It makes it really easy to link to other files (relative links)
It makes it easy to refactor (move stuff around)
It works with markdown. The files are just plain text files in my Files app on my iPhone.



Writing flow
Every writer has their flow. The tools they use should reflect their mental process of writing, and not the other way around. If you‚Äôre trying to get your brain to work like the tool does, rather than using tools that working like your brain, you‚Äôre ngmi. If you‚Äôre like me, you‚Äôll try it for a while and then give up. (I may give up after this post, but at least this post isn‚Äôt saved on Blogger.com!)
Here‚Äôs mine:

Get an idea
Categorize it (religious, tech, life, etc)
Create a file
Mark as draft
Write some ideas
Edit it (if long), reread a few times
Unmark as draft
Post to the internet, read a few more times in live version and make edits
Tag it
Find old drafts, finish them
Add an image, either from my phone camera or chatgpt. Save image in the right folder.
Write alt text to the images.
Create links to other entries.
Make some footnotes for content that doesn‚Äôt flow
Cry and debate if I‚Äôm a good writer or if anyone is even listening anymore
Add a subscribe button
share a good one to social media
Check my Google analytics to see if I‚Äôm popular. Check subscribers to see if I got any. Wonder why I care anyway because I know I won‚Äôt make money off this.
Get an idea for a new post while reading a book and start again

The process of getting ideas from a source, and writing from those ideas, makes me want to be able to connect the entry to the source (book or podcast). Sure, I don‚Äôt have to write. And sometimes writing is wasted time (writing for writing‚Äôs sake), but I enjoy it.


My writing flow with Obsidian and Quarto
At the risk of nobody ever reading this far, I‚Äôll keep this high level, and if someone cares about something ask me in the comments.
First, see Quarto from Phone to see how I set up Working Copy to sync my Obsidian repo with GitHub.
Here‚Äôs my flow with obsidian:

Read a book. Create new book note using new-post via the Templater obsidian plugin. This lets me create a new note in a folder of my choice, give a title, make a filename with a good url slug. Adds some categories automatically.
When idea comes up, take note in book note. When substantial idea comes up, create a quick draft of a new post using Templater. Enable draft: true if i don‚Äôt finish.
Use Obsidian Dataview to create a list of all outstanding drafts. I can come back and finish.
Use Obsidian Custom Sort to sort the files in my repo how I want. This package helped me to stop time-stamping my URLs (which I thought was good for sorting). Instead, I can sort by modified time (note custom sort isn‚Äôt necessary for modified time sorting), but custom sort allows for sorting by yaml front matter.
When I‚Äôm ready to post, create an image using ChatGPT app. Click on the image in the app, share, save to files. It will save to the img/ folder in my root. Next image? Saves here (iPhone remembers).

At some point I was creating folders for every blog post so I could reference images there. I‚Äôm giving this up for two reasons: 1) every file would then need to be named ‚Äúindex.md‚Äù and 2) more folders is more noise. So instead, I have one place for all images, which makes it easier to save and I don‚Äôt have to click a bunch of subfolders every time I add an image.
Also, screenshot any photos you may want to add so as to remove the location metadata.

Use Footnote Shortcut plugin to more efficiently write footnotes. Add a hotkey to the mobile obsidian editor toolbar to quickly add footnotes. 1
Set up an iOS shortcut to do a ‚Äúgit pull‚Äù, ‚Äúgit commit‚Äù, ‚Äúgit push‚Äù on the repo. Put this shortcut on my home page. Since I have a synced folder, this happens very efficiently!2
Set up a github actions to build the blog using quarto render. See Quarto vs.¬†quartz for Obsidian blog
Publish to GitHub pages with the docs/ folder.

And that‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs my flow. If you like this, ask me a question.

You can also set up an automation to sync anytime you leave the app, but I‚Äôve found that gets kind of annoying because sometimes there can be data loss with a git pull that happens without thinking about it.‚Ü©Ô∏é

text:
Imagine you just ran a red light at 10:15pm. You were driving without music or phone distractions, you just zoned out and coasted through.
Your emotions run high as you consider what might have happened otherwise. But nothing happened. Something could have happened, but nothing did. In the end, all is well.

Life is full of thousands of these things. Several of them we recognize and brush off ‚Äúoh that was close.‚Äù But how many events go unnoticed because we were unaware we even could have done harm (no red light to be found)?
How we identify and recover is a skill. How do you process such experiences? How do you get over the person who cuts you off on the highway? How do you get over not realizing you cut someone off?

title: De-sciencing Data Science and Talking Like a Normal Person
text:
Building a Data Science culture






TL;DR: Always keep it simple and always bring it back to the business need.



A coworker once asked me for advice on how to bring technical rigor into a non-technical culture.


When the Simple Solution Wins
A few years back I wanted to see if I could predict which NBA team would win in their next match. FiveThirtyEight is a blog that does this every day. Could I build a model as good as theirs?
I built a few models and put up a site. Below I have a table of accuracies for each of my models compared to FoveThirtyEight‚Äôs.

What I learned is that Nate Silver‚Äôs FiveThirtyEight three models are only 66% accurate. In 20 hours I got a model as accurate (V02 above) as his using just team level data (win %, recent win streak, etc.) and no player data (injuries, etc.). Also my model was built using data from 2005-2017 to predict 2019 performance. His model was updated daily with recent stats.
But even more glaring is that if I made a prediction on a single feature (Home % > Away %) I could achieve 63.7% accuracy. This feature is a 1 if the home teams win % is greater than the away teams win %, 0 otherwise. Meaning, the home team wins 63.7% of the time their season win % is higher than the away teams season win %.
Was it worth building an XGBoost model with 30 features to get 65.8% accuracy when just a simple calculation is 63.7% accurate? Depends on business context and how valuable that 2% gain is and what the development/engineering cost of deploying a model is. But if I were you I‚Äôd start with the simple model to get it into production to start generating value and then come back later to optimize.
Caveat: it took a lot of work to discover that feature. 90% of the problem was building the data set. So at the end, building a model was pretty simple once I had the data. (This is where cloud AutoML will take over going forward, sorry!.) And I needed the model to see the feature importance (this was the top feature.) This is a valid data science approach: use modeling to discover the patterns. But just because you have a model doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs worth deploying.
Keep it business focused: when building a recommendation system, start with ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs most popular‚Äù. Why would you need K-means or whatever to begin? And can‚Äôt you build your own K-means by creating heuristic filters? For example: if you want to recommend me a shirt based on shirts I‚Äôve searched, you can find all shirts of same color, price, and size and recommend those. Building a model to take into account dimensions, patterns, what others buy, etc is fine but should be a V2.


Mindsets
There‚Äôs a temptation to act like an academic professor and use fancy jargon when working with your coworkers. Even worse, there‚Äôs a temptation to think you‚Äôre smarter than your coworkers because you know this mathy thing that they don‚Äôt. But remember this quote:

When they are learned they think they are wise‚Ä¶1

This pride power struggle is your downfall for two reasons:

It blinds you to thinking your solution is good just because someone else can‚Äôt understand it.
It blinds you from focusing on what matters most: getting the simplest and best solution.

Your coworkers aren‚Äôt your students eating you. They‚Äôre your smart coworkers solving the same problems you are.
A better mindset is that of a professional athlete, like a football player. They might be dumb as bricks at times but they‚Äôre all incredibly smart players. Can you explain your technical solution like a pro football player would?

Bad: ‚ÄúI built an XGBoost classification model that reduces the RMSE by minimizing the Gini coefficient on each node‚Ä¶‚Äù

Better: ‚ÄúI noticed that most users close the app after they reach this page. I tried looking at some reasons why and found a few common behaviors (DISCUSS, get feedback). I think we can predict when this will happen and here‚Äôs a framework to do that.‚Äù

There‚Äôs a temptation to think ‚ÄúI did all this technical work, I should get credit for it!‚Äù My manager once coached me, ‚ÄúYour stakeholders should be amazed by how simple you made it. Not by how complicated the problem is.‚Äù
The best example I know of this is Chris Voss, an FBI negotiator. Listen to his podcasts or YouTubes. He‚Äôs a humble guy and doesn‚Äôt get into the technical stuff. He knows the principles and keeps the explanations simple. He helps you feel smart when you listen to him. He‚Äôs one of the best negotiators in the world and if you were having dinner with him you‚Äôd think he was a normal guy. This is how data scientists should be.


Bugs
There are two types of bugs in data science: Software bugs and data bugs. You‚Äôll spend 80% of your ramp up time on a project setting up your environment, learning the data, trying to understand the primary keys and logging and unique values, etc.






Nobody cares about how you do any of this (the same way you don‚Äôt care about how cereal ends up in your grocery store), but they do care that you do it because it shows that you‚Äôre thinking about the right things.
They‚Äôll also worry that you‚Äôre spending too much time on the wrong thing, so make sure you believe your actions are solving a business purpose.





Takeaways

Focus on principles, not technical details.
Get the simplest, useful solution into production first to start creating value. Then figure out if it‚Äôs worth optimizing. If your product gets deprecated in 3 months then the fancy model will be wasted time anyway.
Your stakeholders should be amazed by how simple you made it. Not by how complicated the problem is.
If you can‚Äôt explain a trend with a simple bar/line chart, a fancy regression model won‚Äôt do.
Start with the non-technical (basic math) solution. Then see if you can beat the basic math with a fancy model. Evaluate the cost/benefit of the technical solution relative to the dumb version.
when you have a fancy solution, make sure you compare it to the basic solution. Make sure you can beat the solution your teammates come up with. And make sure you carefully lead them from ‚Äútheir‚Äù solution to yours. ‚ÄúAt first I tried X. X was fine. But X didn‚Äôt account for Y. So I built a model M and saw that M out performs X by 10%.‚Äù
Just because you know/use math, doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs right for the business. Data Scientists can easily be myopic because the work we do is challenging and deep in the weeds.
Your boss doesn‚Äôt care about the nature of the bugs, but you should try to bring first principles to the table so she can cover for you. ‚ÄúI keep hitting this bug in the data. Can we ask/work with Infra team to solve this because it eats my time.‚Äù

title: How to mock the value of an ML solution
text:
IBM once launched a demo of speech-to-text in the early day‚Äôs of the technology. But there was a twist: it was smoke and mirrors. A typist in behind the stage was translating and typing.
This is a mechanical Turk.
In data science, we can present results or dashboards to audience members before they see anything. If you see a big reaction, you know you found a number they cared about.
Go ahead, write the conclusion first. Fake the chart first. Then back out the code that could produce the insights they need.
Sometimes, unique insights appear along the way. But most of the time you can properly gut-check whether someone will care about what you‚Äôre doing. Save time. Work backward.

title: Pomodoro Principles
text:
I‚Äôve been trying a Pomodoro timer in TickTick and it‚Äôs changing how I approach my work day. I‚Äôve been using it for two days so far and here are the differences I notice:

When my mind knows I‚Äôll get a break at 25 minutes, it allows me to focus more.

A 5 min break is perfect.

I used to hate timing myself after working in consulting. I vowed I would never work on the clock ever again. But don‚Äôt the best athletes pace themselves? Any marathon trainer knows how to set a pace and have rest periods. Why wouldn‚Äôt the same principles apply to cognitive work?

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Structured
The highest rated app for planning on the App Store is ‚ÄúStructured‚Äù. Where this app excels is it‚Äôs simplicity. It‚Äôs likely best for someone like a student that wants to plan out when they‚Äôll get their homework done. What I loved about this app, and what I wish many others apps had, is a duration estimation for a task. Why is it so hard for developers to realize that tasks take time? They obsess over list keeping and app design but ignore the second most basic question: how long will this take? Structured kind of solves this. What I don‚Äôt like about this app is the design. While others praise it for its beauty and simplicity I thought the visual feel of it was distracting.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Microsoft To Do
Microsoft To Do used to be a favorite of mine. I loved its daily planner and smart suggestions. It has the philosophy that every day you should start fresh. All unfinished tasks will be removed from today and you‚Äôre left to pick and choose what you want to do. The fatal limitation however is that it lacks the ability to plan tomorrows a tasks the day before. So this forces people to have to populate their tasks at the start of the day. This is the worst time for planning for me because I want to get up and get going ASAP. (But honestly most times I wake up 15 minutes before my first meeting or am spending time pouring milk into my kids‚Äô cereal.) Morning is not the best time to plan a day for me, so I lost interest here.



To Do has smart text parsing.





To Do has ‚Äúsmart suggestions‚Äù that you can add to your day.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Todoist
I‚Äôve tried many times to get into Todoist. It has smart text parsing which is apparently best in class from my Reddit research.
Things it has:

Projects can have section labels. This lets you organize your list more meaningfully. This is great, only that TickTick does it better. Each project in TickTick can have subprojects. These subprojects act like sections. You can also move subproject from one list to another.


Things it lacks:

Can‚Äôt nest labels (tags)
Can‚Äôt create labels dynamically - you need to manually add them on the label screen before a task can leverage them.
Can‚Äôt pull in my calendar.
Doesn‚Äôt have check items, only subtasks.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Sorted3
This app takes a different design. It‚Äôs main selling point is the ability to auto schedule your day based on the tasks you have for that day.
Pros:

Rich formatting on description. Supports markdown.
clean UI. Good shortcuts.
integrates with calendar to plan your day.
Easily plan duration.

Really nice widgets.

Cons:

Doesn‚Äôt have subtasks, but has check boxes
No prioritization or smart filters. Just tags and lists.
Can‚Äôt easily see across lists like you can in TickTick

Auto schedule is nice but could be kind of gimmicky. If you have 8 meetings in a day and five 30 min free blocks but all your tasks for the day are an hour, it would put all your tasks at the end of the day. I found it kind of buggy.

title: What is the best todo list manager?
text:
Automated
Motion became popular as a calendar organizer. Add a task and Motion will figure out when to do that for you. If you change your meeting then Motion will adjust when your tasks will get done. Cons: it‚Äôs expensive ($20-$35 per month). It‚Äôs mobile app is horrid. It didn‚Äôt seem like it offered sub tasks and all that. So you really need to trust the algorithm.

It gets the notion of task-duration right. But if you want to jot down notes of all the next actions you need to take on a project, your up the creek. I‚Äôm also not sure how it handles task dependency - if I put in 5 tasks for a project will it know their order? Not sure. Again I‚Äôve never tried this app so take this all with a grain of salt.
Reclaim is another app claiming to do the same thing and offers a free tier. I did as much as set up my account with this.
Perhaps if I gave these more attention they‚Äôd prove their worth. I‚Äôve tried calendaring my todos in the past and it hasn‚Äôt been very effective for me. Perhaps these apps would solve it but I think I need a good mobile app.
Anyway, you can‚Äôt beat free and free is working for me on TickTick right now. Also, my calendar is very open generally so I don‚Äôt have the same problems a busy manager might have.
I think these apps would be best for people who have meeting heavy workflows. It handles the schedules as you need.

title: Data Beats Opinions
text:
When I co-started a company several years ago, my founders and I would canvass neighborhoods knocking doors. We‚Äôd discuss our ideas for a new product one door at a time. After each conversation, the product took a new form. Eventually, the product took shape and we had a successful kickstarter launch.
Since that time, I‚Äôve thought about how valuable it was to get information straight from the source.
Alberto Savoia‚Äôs new book, ‚ÄúThe Right It‚Äù, is re-teaching me this principle. Data beats opinions, he says. In another book I‚Äôm reading, ‚ÄúTrustworthy Online Controlled Experiments‚Äù, the former CEO of Netscape is quoted saying,

If we have data, let‚Äôs go with data. If all we have are opinions, let‚Äôs go with mine. - Jim Barksdale

Data sourced from your manager, your stakeholder, or your customer are invaluable to help you know if you‚Äôre solving their problem. Too often it‚Äôs easy to get stuck in the original solution that comes to our mind.
Data from customers directly shape the product. Data sourced at scale from online experiments refine it.
Opinions from the customer shape the product. Their behavior (captured as data) speaks louder than their words. Frequently, it‚Äôs challenging to correlate the two. We‚Äôre left to guess why someone actually clicked, bought, churned. It‚Äôs a beautiful cycle.

title: The Allegory of the Dodo
text:
The scoop
There‚Äôs a great kids book, called ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a dodo on the wedding cake‚Äù.
So there‚Äôs this dodo, right, who walks in and hops on a cake. The attending violinist then scares it away and is praised for protecting the cake.
To the reader‚Äôs delight, more animals start appearing and the violinist excitedly protects the cake through hilarious misadventure. (My favorite is when he says, ‚Äúbegone beavers!‚Äù)
Two funny things happen though:

The guy soon realizes that all these creatures are wedding guests.
The guy has such a big nose and he‚Äôs allergic to marshmallows, that when he‚Äôs offered some cake he sneezes and the cake goes flying.




dodo on a cake




Morale?

When you praise someone for doing something good, they do it again and again. ‚Üí There‚Äôs a natural hero inside all of us.
But only the first animal was a problem. The beavers were the chefs. So he ends up creating all these problems thinking they‚Äôre problems. ‚Üí In tech, when you fix a bug you then think other things are bugs and go off fixing those too. No, just do the first. Then check in.
The irony is that, despite saving the cake, he sneezes and ruins the cake. ‚Üí Despite all the effort, the greatest protection to the cake was him staying away from it. Sometimes by trying to solve a problem we can make things way worse and create all these problems. (Politics? Create problems by creating solutions to problems that need solutions.)

Don‚Äôt mistake a beaver for a dodo. But don‚Äôt mistake a dodo for a wedding guest.

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 1
text:
Get the data
In order to do any good analaysis, you first need data. I prefer to have more data than less, where possible. In this case, I don‚Äôt have any data, so I use webscraping to get the data. There are much better tutorials on how to scrape data, so I‚Äôll be light. I use R‚Äôs rvest package here, which does a decent job.1 Let‚Äôs look at Truecar‚Äôs Used Car postings2. First I use google to find the search query on Truecar that I like.

title: Buying a used car the data science way: Part 1
text:
Load packages

library(rvest)
library(dplyr)
library(magrittr)
# Find the URL of the data you want to scrape
url <- 'https://www.truecar.com/used-cars-for-sale/listings/ford/edge/'
read_html(url)

## {xml_document}
## <html lang="en-US">
## [1] <head>\n<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset= ...
## [2] <body>\n    <!-- Element target for any partner code meant to execut ...
You‚Äôll see there‚Äôs a head and a body. Our data‚Äôs in the body, so let‚Äôs use html_nodes() and html_text() to parse out the data we want. I used Selectorgadget to know what HTML classes to search for.

read_html(url) %>% html_nodes('.col-xs-6.col-sm-8.no-left-padding') %>% html_text()

## character(0)
So that‚Äôs how you get the data on a single page. If you look closer at the URL, you see a lot of helpful things. First, there‚Äôs the make, then the model, then the location-zip, then the year-range, and ultimately the trim. This is a very pretty and clean URL. If you click on a few additional pages, you‚Äôll see the URL opens up with ?page=2.
https://www.truecar.com/used-cars-for-sale/listings/ford/edge/location-90210/?page=2
This is our ‚Äòin‚Äô to scraping multiple pages. I won‚Äôt bore you with the details of how to get that data into a neat matrix for us to analyze, but suffice it to say that I‚Äôm able to do it. Just build a function to construct a URL, and build a loop to go through the different pages, then use lots of str_extract() from the stringr package and gsub to clean up the data.

library(stringr)

make = 'ford'
model = 'edge'
zip = '90210'
year = 2012
npages = 5

url <- paste('https://www.truecar.com/used-cars-for-sale/listings/', 
             make, '/', 
             model ,
             '/location-', zip,
             '/year-',year,'-max/?page=', sep = "")

urls <- paste(url, 1:npages, sep = "")

scrape <- function(pageno){
  try(
    read_html(urls[pageno]) %>% html_nodes('.col-xs-6.col-sm-8.no-left-padding') %>% html_text()
  )
}

long_list = scrape(1)
for(i in 2:npages){
  print(i)
  new_list = try(scrape(i))
  
  error = ("try-error" %in% class(new_list))
  
  if( error == FALSE ){
    long_list = c(long_list, new_list) 
  } else {
    break
  }
}
## [1] 2
stats <- long_list
df <- as.data.frame(stats)
df$stats %<>% as.character()
df$price <- str_extract(df$stats, '\\$[0-9]*,[0-9]*') %>% 
  gsub('Price: |\\$|,', '', .) %>%
  as.numeric()
df$year <- str_extract(df$stats, '^[0-9]* ') %>% 
  as.numeric()
df$mileage <- str_extract(df$stats, 'Mileage: [0-9]*,[0-9]*') %>% 
  gsub('Mileage: |,', '', .) %>%
  as.numeric()

# a = df$stats[1]
df$trim <- str_extract(df$stats, '.*Mileage:') %>% 
  gsub('FWD|AWD|4x[24]|[24]WD|V6|4-cyl|^[0-9][0-9][0-9][0-9]|4dr|Automatic|Manual|Mileage:', '', ., ignore.case = T) %>% 
  gsub(make, '', ., ignore.case = T) %>% 
  gsub(model, '', ., ignore.case = T) %>% 
  trimws() 


df$awd <- grepl('AWD|4WD|4x4', df$stats, ignore.case = T) %>% as.numeric()
df$manual <- grepl('manual', df$stats) %>% as.numeric()
df$v6 <- grepl('V6', df$stats) %>% as.numeric()
df$location <- str_extract(df$stats, 'Location: .*Exterior:') %>% 
  gsub('Location: |Exterior:', '', .) %>% 
  trimws() 
df$ext <- str_extract(df$stats, 'Exterior: .*Interior:') %>% 
  gsub('Interior:|Exterior:', '', .) %>% 
  trimws() 
df$int <- str_extract(df$stats, 'Interior: .*VIN:') %>% 
  gsub('Interior: |VIN:', '', .) %>% 
  trimws() 
df$vin <- str_extract(df$stats, 'VIN: .*\\$') %>% 
  gsub('VIN: |\\$', '', .) %>% 
  substr(., 1, 17)
df$deal <- str_extract(df$stats, '\\$[0-9]*,[0-9]* below') %>% 
  gsub('below|\\$|,', '', .) %>% trimws() %>%
  as.numeric()

And here‚Äôs what the results look like. You‚Äôve got the original scraped data in the stats column and then everything else that you can parse out.

# df was the dataframe object we needed
df %>% select(-stats) %>% head(10) %>% formattable::formattable()

title: 30 Seconds is All You Get
text:
Apple iTunes changed the music industry forever with one simple decision: the preview of a song should be 30 seconds long.
This little change dramatically altered how music sounds today. I‚Äôve recently listened to some bangers that were only 90 seconds long. They left me hanging.



Enjoy the music while it lasts


Why was my song so short? Because nobody gets paid after 30 seconds.

Apple‚Äôs decision made artists want to have more interesting 30 seconds in the iTunes Store
That evolved into: an artist doesn‚Äôt get paid if you don‚Äôt listen at least 30 seconds. And they don‚Äôt get paid any more if you listen 31 or 900 seconds. In fact, they get paid more if you listen to two songs, 30s a piece.

Spotify, Amazon, YouTube, Apple, etc all pay based on views. They each define views their own way, but they need to negotiate with the labels who already decided to agree to Apple‚Äôs 30s schemes in the early 2000‚Äôs. They may have different payment schemes, but some have a scheme of ‚Äútake all revenue, distribute it according to the artist‚Äôs share of views.‚Äù So if I pay $10/mo for Spotify and don‚Äôt use it, my money goes to someone I didn‚Äôt listen to.
So how do small artists compete? They‚Äôve got to build their following. Proportionally, the major artists (rather, their labels) soak up all the streaming royalties.
What would be more fair is if my $10 went to the artists I actually listened to, as if I bought their music.
Why does any of this matter? Algorithms. Optimization. Monetization.
Incentives drive outcomes. How we designed our music payment incentives altered music forever (try to be super catchy for 30s). Now, with AI, music can be created much faster which will dilute the pool.
In the end, one simple decision changed billions of lives. 30s? That‚Äôs all you need to get paid.

title: Your Mood is Contagious
text:
Moods flow. Keep the negative waves at bay


There‚Äôs no question that moods are contagious. I once asked someone at the beach to leash their dog, and they slightly rebuked me, ‚Äúthis is a dog friendly beach.‚Äù Well, so it is, I thought, grumpily. I complained to a family member about this grumpy dog owner.
Moods escalate. And negative moods are even more pervasive and contagious than positive ones. They say a disgruntled customer tells more friends and family than happy ones. Why is this?
In the ‚ÄúBlack Cat‚Äù (The Best of Edgar Allen Poe), Poe describes a gruesome tale man who wanted to do evil just for the sake of it. That it‚Äôs in his nature. Not because you want to do the thing, but because you want to do a forbidden thing. The same goes the other way, for sure. But I think we trend slightly pessimistic because being an optimist is more beneficial, more rewarding and therefore more difficult.
A leader once told me when I was managing a team, ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll pick up on everything you do or say.‚Äù Oddly, I was picking up on what he was saying.
So when you lead, lead carefully. Whether in home or work, lead with kindness, compassion, and restraint. Speak three kind words before a negative. Ask to understand before assuming. Lead as a servant. It takes all the effort to overcome negative vibes, and who better equipped than the leader to do it?
Don‚Äôt be Moriarty:

‚ÄúWhy can‚Äôt you be more hopeful for a change?‚Äù

title: Goals
text:
Public accountability is the greatest motivator.











These goals are correlated with, but not causal to happiness.





They‚Äôre anti-sad, but pro-happy comes not from checking off boxes but by building meaningful relationships with God, self, family, and friends.
Why do I measure? Because whenever things aren‚Äôt going well I often attribute it to a lacking of one of these things. But I don‚Äôt keep this checkbox list to make me happy. Happiness is perspective and relationships. Purpose. So why this list? Well, they‚Äôre the foundation of a guided, structured, and prosperous life.

Studying scriptures and praying teaches me who I am and what my purpose is here on earth. It also gives me perfect role models to follow (Christ‚Äôs example in the scriptures, and God‚Äôs influence on me during prayer). What better way to guide your rudder (as Christensen says), than to be influenced by God on a daily basis. They say you‚Äôre the average of the 5 people you spend the most time with. Why not make the number 1 person you spend your most valuable time to be God? (I don‚Äôt have to spend 5 hours. 5 very meaningful minutes can correct my day.)
Writing about my study is my little attempt to share God‚Äôs light with the world. Imagine what social media would look like if everyone shared an insight from Marcus Aurelius, Buddha, Ghandi, Jesus, Mohammad, on a daily basis and how that insight affected their perspective? Be the change you want to see in the world, they say.
Writing gratitude rewires my brain. It causes me to see things I wouldn‚Äôt. Why not just say things I‚Äôm grateful for during prayer or a gratitude journal? I dunno. Those things don‚Äôt help me for some reason. It always feels forced (I‚Äôve tried it dozens of ways). Somehow, writing in public, gives me a great sense of ‚ÄúI mean it.‚Äù Helps me think about that thing. Give it real thought.
Physical health. Strength helps my bones. The effects of weight lifting are seen over decades, not months. I need to take better care of my bones. Same with cardio. They both energize today, but they prevent a whole host of bad things tomorrow and beyond. The effects are compounding - in both directions. Physical health also drives me to eat better. Eating better doesn‚Äôt cause me to exercise, but exercising caueses me to eat better. Less snacks.
Meditating helps me train my mind. It‚Äôs a moment where I think about something I want to improve on. Less reactivity as a dad to kids misbehaving. More optimism. More appreciation for the body I have, the health I enjoy, the freedom I have in this world.

title: An Unknown God
text:
This post speaks to how I manage spiritual doubts, such as whether God exists. It got me thinking after reading a few religious posts by Rob Hybdman, someone whose professional (data science) work I greatly admire.
Here‚Äôs a summary of some points I try to make here:

He doesn‚Äôt try to convince us to believe Him without a doubt, He asks us to follow him
People who saw Christ didn‚Äôt even recognize Him as the Savior
Christianity is hard to grasp and won‚Äôt make total sense when you think deeply about it.
Our job is to keep learning, and ask Him to teach us about His nature




I think too many people grow up thinking of God in black/white terms and when one, linking piece of the puzzle doesn‚Äôt fit or is missing, some throw Him out all together. Here‚Äôs my take on why people misrepresent God, and how this can lead to personal doubts of faith in Him and His Son.



Christ asking his disciples, ‚ÄúWhom say he that I am?‚Äù



An unknown God
A certain philosopher named Korihor once reasoned that people should stop paying tithing or following restrictive religious commandments because they‚Äôre wasting their time. Here‚Äôs his thinking:

Yea, they durst not make use of that which is their own lest they should offend their priests, who do yoke them according to their desires, and have brought them to believe, ==by their traditions and their dreams and their whims and their visions== and their ==pretended mysteries==, that they should, if they did not do according to their words, ==offend some unknown being, who they say is God==‚Äîa being who never has been seen or known, who never was nor ever will be. - Alma 30:28

I love this because the argument of whether God exists or if Christ was the Savior is nothing new. (And many people I highly regard and esteem are tackling this ‚Äúnew‚Äù issue head on, as many in the world are questioning their faith.) But a lot of the same arguments that have existed continue to exist: why believe?
‚Ä¶It‚Äôs not like anyone‚Äôs ever seen God anyway.
Let‚Äôs assume for a minute that they have seen God. They saw His Son, His mortal example, walk the earth (John 5:19).
While with His disciples, Christ himself took a moment to reflect on who people thought he was, and whether people actually recognized Him for who He is:

When Jesus came into the coasts of C√¶sarea Philippi, he asked his disciples, saying, ==Whom do men say that I the Son of man am?== And they said, Some say that thou art John the Baptist: some, Elias; and others, Jeremias, or one of the prophets. Matthews 16:13-14

People had no idea who Christ was even though I‚Äôd bet either He or His disciples them His name many times while He was healing them.
People are funny like that.
Consider your own life. Have you ever misinterpreted a situation, even as it‚Äôs being explained to you?
Let‚Äôs consider a magician who does a magic trick for you. She doesn‚Äôt show you how it‚Äôs done, but she does explain it to you with only words. Since you don‚Äôt specifically see how the magic trick is done, perhaps your mind wanders and you doubt what really happened.
Do you trust the Magician? When He tells you who He is, after healing you, do you believe Him? When an unexplainable coincidence happens in your life, what do you chalk it up to?

‚ÄúNah, that‚Äôs so highly improbable it must just be luck‚Äù‚Ä¶ (whatever luck is‚Ä¶)

I can‚Äôt imagine how it must have felt for people around Christ to be healed by rubbing mud on their eyes or washing in a river a few times or, or, ‚Ä¶ I can only honestly believe these people felt absolute wonder to the point of mental disassociation. How else do you mentally cope with being a paralytic your whole life and then you‚Äôre able to walk?
It‚Äôs entirely reasonable, then, that they just figured He must be like the other miracle workers they knew - Elias, John the Baptist, etc. They try to frame Him in their believable mental reference, i.e., ‚Äúluck‚Äù.


A strange God
Perhaps though we can relate to when Paul, a lifelong Non-Christian and Christian persecuter, preached to his fellow Gentiles:

16 Now while Paul waited for them at Athens, his spirit was stirred in him, when he saw the city wholly given to idolatry. 17 Therefore ==disputed he in the synagogue with the Jews==, and with the devout persons, and in the market daily with them that met with him. 18 ==Then certain philosophers== of the Epicureans, and of the Stoicks, encountered him. And some said, ==What will this babbler say?== other some, He seemeth to be a setter forth of strange gods: because he preached unto them Jesus, and the resurrection. Acts 17:16-18

Paul got them. He was once like them: a gentile. An unbeliever. A disbeliever. But he eventually was converted to knowing Christ, and, as such, appeared to seem like a babbler when trying to talk to people who once were like him. They considered him and his teachings strange:

19 And they took him, and brought him unto Areopagus, saying, ==May we know what this new doctrine==, whereof thou speakest, is? 20 For ==thou bringest certain strange things to our ears==: we would know therefore what these things mean. Acts 16:19-20

Meeting Christ can be strange.
Understanding him, so too.


Putting a box on God
Consider the question, ‚Äúwhy does God let good people suffer?‚Äù
(Other important questions like, ‚Äúwhy did God encourage Abraham/Isaac/Israel to be polygamists but Adam not?‚Äù, or ‚Äúwhy did God restrict the entire earth from receiving his Gospel until after Christ died, commanding His people not to marry or mingle with them but then change his tone ~33 AD?‚Äù, are worth similar consideration.)
It‚Äôs a false dichotomy: if God exists and loves us, He surely wouldn‚Äôt let us suffer. If suffering exists, especially of good1 people, God must not then exist.
Consider all the suffering of innocent children2. The reality of human nature is sufferers vs non sufferers3. Any suffering is painful to bear, and nobody better understands this than Christ himself (D&C 19:16-19).
The point is, we can falsely equivocate that because God loves us and He had the power to stop suffering, He should stop it.
Do you do this with any other relationship? Consider the hypothetical:

Father Joe loves his children. But Joe let his son Bob get hit with a toy by little sister Susie. Joe let Susie suffer. Therefore, Joe acted in an evil and therefore does not exist.

This line of thinking is absurd to anyone with a brain, let alone to anyone who is a parent. They understand that sufferig is part of life, can be good for teaching, and that it doesn‚Äôt mean the parent doesn‚Äôt exist. Yet sometimes we wonder if God exists because we‚Äôre suffering.


Consider alternative viewpoints
To be comfortable with unanswered questions from a yet unknown God, we should consider how the question is already answered.
For example, did God stop Christ from suffering? No.¬†Did Christ stop himself from suffering on the cross when He had the power to turn water to wine for the thirsty, heal the suffering swordsman‚Äôs ear, or even raise Himself from the dead?
I‚Äôm trying to rally around the point: we set up for ourselves false philosophical arguments about who or what God is and should be like when there‚Äôs a lot of nuance to be considered.
In my view, He‚Äôs more of a Magician who ‚Äúexplains but doesn‚Äôt show‚Äù than one who tries ‚Äúto convince us about every little thing‚Äù. Because it‚Äôs quite human to be like ‚Äúoh, yea that magic trick isn‚Äôt cool anymore‚Äù once you understand it. And His goal is to invite us to believe His son so that we‚Äôll follow Him. His goal isn‚Äôt for us to know everything, though he is willing to teach us a lot. Remember: ‚Äúask and ye shall receive‚Äù.

And now come, saith the Lord, by the Spirit‚Ä¶and let us reason together, ==that ye may understand;== D&C 50:10

He just didn‚Äôt say when He‚Äôd tell us.


Why he explains but doesn‚Äôt try to convince
Why do I believe that He likes to explain but not convince? A few ideas:

He taught people they would get to heaven by eating His flesh (sacrament), and people misunderstood and thought this was a ‚Äúhard‚Äù teaching. They walked no more with him (John 6), but he didn‚Äôt run them down to try to bring them back. Why didn‚Äôt he?4
He was chained by the Romans, spat on, crowned with thorns, and whipped. But instead of showing them signs and wonders He let them abuse Him. Then He forgave them after they nailed Him to the cross multiple times and speared Him in His side and gave Him vinegar to drink (Psalm 69, John 19).
He knew He couldn‚Äôt convince them. He once healed a withered man‚Äôs hands and the Pharisees wanted to destroy Him because he did so on the sabbath (Matthew 12:9-14)5. How too are we like the Pharisees where we say ‚ÄúGod shouldn‚Äôt be like X!!!‚Äù Shouldn‚Äôt we instead let God reveal Himself?

These three clues, among many others, give me perspective on why He‚Äôs okay being misunderstood by us.


A God of purpose, children of purpose and promise
Why does He want us to live by faith? Lots of reasons. But there‚Äôs only one I‚Äôll speak to: He‚Äôs a God of purpose:

37 And the Lord God spake unto Moses, saying: The heavens, they are many, and they cannot be numbered unto man; but they are numbered unto me, for they are mine. 38 And as one earth shall pass away, and the heavens thereof even so shall another come; and there is no end to my works, neither to my words. 39 For behold, ==this is my work and my glory‚Äîto bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man==. - Moses 1:37-39

His goal is to prepare an environment to teach and challenge us. Our goal should be to learn who, how and why.
Our purpose should not be to put God in a box or imagine Him black and white. It should be to learn who He is, so He‚Äôa no longer an unknown God.

And this is life eternal, that they might know thee the only true God, and Jesus Christ, whom thou hast sent. - John 17:3







What is Good without God?‚Ü©Ô∏é
The world is filled with unjust, seemingly unnecessary suffering. Consider innocent children starving across the world, being bombed in Gaza/raped in Israel, bombed in Ukraine, Yemen, gassed in Germany in the Holocaust, starved in Stalin‚Äôs camps, nuked by the United States in Japan, etc, etc, etc. (I sincerely don‚Äôt write this easily, nor to make light of the suffering.) all of the suffering is horrible. But it doesn‚Äôt for a moment mean God doesn‚Äôt exist. It actually affirms His existence, because if evil exists the opposite of evil must too.‚Ü©Ô∏é
I don‚Äôt mean that in the Marxist political sense, because who‚Äôs to declare who‚Äôs suffering at any given moment? Is an affluent child born with cancer not a sufferer despite them not being poor?‚Ü©Ô∏é
Consider this in a humorous way: Why didn‚Äôt He say ‚Äúoh sorry!! Please come back! I‚Äôve got a quota of disciples to reach and if I don‚Äôt have you with me‚Ä¶‚Äù‚Äù‚Ü©Ô∏é
I love how instead of engaging with the Pharisees, He ‚Äúwithdrew‚Äù from them and ‚Äúhealed them all‚Äù, kind of as a divine rebel just saying, ‚Äúyou‚Äôre mad about me healing one guy on the Sabbath? Fine, I‚Äôll heal everyone.‚Äù‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: How I use the Book of Mormon
text:
The Book of Mormon is the most powerful book I‚Äôve read.
This is how I get the most out of the book:

I say unto you that ye must pray always, and not faint; that ye must not perform any thing unto the Lord save in the first place ye shall pray unto the Father in the name of Christ, that he will consecrate thy performance unto thee, that thy performance may be for the welfare of thy soul. 2 Nephi 32.9

I‚Äôve read a lot of self help books. It‚Äôs not like that. This is a book that inspires personal revelation and a relationship with Christ and Heavenly Father. I get the most out of it when I have a true desire in my heart:

And when ye shall receive these things, I would exhort you that ye would ask God, the Eternal Father, in the name of Christ, if these things are not true; and if ye shall ask with a sincere heart, with real intent, having faith in Christ, he will manifest the truth of it unto you, by the power of the Holy Ghost. Moroni 10.4

When I read it in a rush, I don‚Äôt get much out of it. When I don‚Äôt pray before hand, or if I‚Äôm not sincere, I don‚Äôt really get anything substantive.
It‚Äôs like texting vs calling a friend. If you‚Äôre in a rush, you give a half thought text. But if you‚Äôre on a long drive and want to build a relationship, you give the friend a call.



If you plant a seed, you need to nourish it


The best insight doesn‚Äôt come from the Book of Mormon. It comes from the Holy Ghost. So I can read the book as a literary critique and not see its divinity. But as I read it trying to build a relationship with Heavenly Father, then I feel that relationship grow.

Now, we will compare the word unto a seed. Now, if ye give place, that a seed may be planted in your heart, behold, if it be a true seed, or a good seed, if ye do not cast it out by your unbelief, that ye will resist the Spirit of the Lord, behold, it will begin to swell within your breasts; and when you feel these swelling motions, ye will begin to say within yourselves‚ÄîIt must needs be that this is a good seed, or that the word is good, for it beginneth to enlarge my soul; yea, it beginneth to enlighten my understanding, yea, it beginneth to be delicious to me. Alma 32.28

title: The Christ Child
text:
The story of the Savior‚Äôs birth brings many wonderful concepts to memory and can teach us a lot about what will bring us true joy and happiness in this life.



The Christ Child


This is my favorite video of the Christmas story. The most powerful part is the moment when Mary sings a lullaby to Jesus. I remember reading somewhere that this moment was completely impromptu by the actress, and it speaks volumes to the sacredness of the moment where Mary first laid eyes on her beloved son.

So what does this story give me perspective on at this time of year?

Christ was the rightful, bloodline heir to King David‚Äôs throne. He was the King of the Jews. But he never sought authority. He never sought a throne. He instead taught ‚ÄúRender therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar‚Äôs‚Äù. He didn‚Äôt engage in turf battles. In rebellion. In insurrection. He just wanted people to find happiness in their circumstances by living with lovingkindness in their hearts for their God, their neighbor, and themselves.
In his role as a Savior and Judge of the world, he sought to not condemn the sinner trapped in the act of sin. Instead he came to liberate. To forgive. To support.
If you believe Christ was the Creator and Savior of the world, consider how He chose to come into the world. He was born in a stable, mucked with animal feces and rotting food scraps, covered with the stench of‚Ä¶a stable. He was rejected of a room in the inn. He was laid in a manger, perhaps a feeding trough. Maybe Mary had help giving birth, maybe she didn‚Äôt. He was born generally alone. I wonder if He chose to do his birth this way because nobody can say he had it easy. He didn‚Äôt have the special treatment of a King‚Äôs birth. No, he was born to an exhausted, weary traveler, likely on the cold hard floor of a dirty barn.
If we think about the Savior being the architect of this birth, think about how he planned for angels to show up to shepherds. Not King Herod. The shepherds. He would be the prophesied sacrificial Lamb. He would be the Good Shepherd. Yet these people were perhaps the minimum wage, forgotten ones outside the city gate. Yet these are those who had the privilege to see Him first. And He invited them to come and see. His whole life was an invitation.
He also invited the rich wise men. All are invited. He wanted all to see, and he wanted the world to know that He was for everyone regardless their circumstances. And that all of us, whether destitute or traveling with caravans, can bring the gifts of our heart to Him. We don‚Äôt need to bring gold. He just wants a ‚Äúbroken heart and contrite spirit.

How can we apply these things to our life, today?

Seek out the forgotten. The people in our life that seem forgotten. The servants in our life (person on the other end of the customer support line, the checkout person, your supervisor) but even, your best friend who seems to be doing great‚Ä¶
Seek not riches or wealth. Harod sought these things. Christ sought relationships and truth.
Don‚Äôt seek for power. Christ deserved it. Christ had it. He turned water to wine, cursed a tree, and made a host of men fall over at the sound of his voice. Yet he didn‚Äôt touch the Romans.
Seek to invite. To share. To uplift. Christ made shepherds feel important. He invited them to his crib side. And ‚Äù his hand is stretched out still.‚Äù (Isaiah 9:12)

He came like all of us, as a child. But he came to show us how a God would live. And he did.



The Christ as a Child, before worshipping Wise men

title: Love Thy Neighbor, But Have Friends
text:
Christ invited us to love our neighbors:

thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself: I am the Lord. Leviticus 19.18

But He himself had his friends: his disciples. He didn‚Äôt try hanging out with the Pharisees or the Romans. He spent time at dinner with his apostles and followers.
He had four brothers. Did he call them to apostleship? No.¬†Did he not love them? No, he loved them.
He loved the Roman as much as he loved John the Beloved: enough to die for them and prepare the way for them to rejoin him in heaven.
But he also spent time with those he loved. What does this teach us about love?

title: My testimony: Moving across the Country
text:
Today is fast Sunday, a day when testimonies are shared in church. Here‚Äôs my testimony I shared today. Someone had just spoken about moving to a new place and seeing God in their lives, even if it was far away from where they had thought they needed to be. They had moved away from family.
I was reminded today of why I live where I do. Without going into personal details, as a family we decided it was time to leave the east coast and move west. As I wondered how it might be possible, I was encouraged by my wife to reach out to an old contact on a random spreadsheet I had kept seven years prior when I was first looking for jobs. The guy had since changed jobs from when he had interviewed me, but he referred me to his new company.
Well, this company was otherwise impossible to get noticed at, even with referrals. Turns out this guy was a lot higher than I had known. It was enough to get me the first interview. Four years later we‚Äôre still on the west coast. It‚Äôs definitely a better situation for our family in many ways.



Moving because when we had a desire, the Lord opened the door for us


And in terms of family, I grew up living far away from cousins. My church congregation became my family. My parents friends became my Sunday school teachers and mentors. My friends at church became my closest confidants and kept me company in living the principles I believed in.
Recently, this church family helped us with meals, gifts, and emotional warmth. I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôd do without belonging to a group of people who care for one another (I know many communities are like this, but I think it‚Äôs extra special in a Christian context where everyone wants to help and strengthen each other in kindness. We all try their best.)
Christ‚Äôs design that we have a church is inspired:

There is one body, and one Spirit, even as ye are called in one hope of your calling; One Lord, one faith, one baptism, One God and Father of all, who is above all, and through all, and in you all. Ephesians 4.4‚Äì6

And are we not all family? The spiritual children of Christ and sons and daughters of Heavenly Father.

And now, because of the covenant which ye have made ye shall be called the children of Christ, his sons, and his daughters; for behold, this day he hath spiritually begotten you; for ye say that your hearts are changed through faith on his name; therefore, ye are born of him and have become his sons and his daughters. ‚Ä¶ therefore, I would that ye should take upon you the name of Christ‚Ä¶ Mosiah 5.7‚Äì8

I testify the Hand of God is real. He leads and guides people to where they need to be gathered. And when we gather together as one body, miracles happen.

I also love this scripture, how Lehi was guided to a ‚Äúland of promise‚Äù.

behold, I have obtained a land of promise 1 Nephi 5.5

He wrote ‚Äúhave obtained‚Äù while he was struggling for food and water in the desert. He saw ahead to when he‚Äôd eventually live in a near rain forest paradise.

title: Scriptures within Scriptures
text:
The Scriptures are precious and worth our time


Nephi recounts how they had obtained some scriptures:

And we had obtained the records which the Lord had commanded us, and searched them and found that they were desirable; yea, even of great worth unto us, insomuch that we could preserve the commandments of the Lord unto our children. 1 Nephi 5.21

A few things that stand out to me:

He thought about his children. In 2 Nephi 25.26 it‚Äôs mentioned ‚Äúthat our children may know to what source they may look for a remission of their sins.‚Äù
They had the scriptures because they accomplished the task laid before them, ‚ÄúI know that the Lord giveth no commandments unto the children of men, save he shall prepare a way for them that they may accomplish the thing which he commandeth them.‚Äù 1 Nephi 3.7
These scriptures were ‚Äúdesirable‚Äù. Know what else is desirable? The fruit of the tree of life:


And it came to pass that I beheld a tree, whose fruit was desirable to make one happy. 1 Nephi 8.10

The scriptures, especially the Book of Mormon, are precious to help our families know of Christ, have been obtained and written by those obedient to Christ, and are desirable and great to consume.
In A Knife to a Gun Fight: Why I‚Äôm off Social Media, I talk about how tech workers talk of social media as ‚Äúsnackable content‚Äù. Frequently the word ‚Äúconsumption‚Äù is used to describe how app ‚Äúusers‚Äù ‚Äúconsume‚Äù content.
It‚Äôs mostly not the stuff worth consuming in great quantities. Don‚Äôt settle for snacks. Enjoy a feast:

Wherefore, do not spend money for that which is of no worth, nor your labor for that which cannot satisfy. Hearken diligently unto me, and remember the words which I have spoken; and come unto the Holy One of Israel, and feast upon that which perisheth not, neither can be corrupted, and let your soul delight in fatness. 2 Nephi 9.51

Replace ‚Äúmoney‚Äù with ‚Äútime‚Äù.

title: His is the light that we should share
text:
When Christ was teaching his disciples, he invited them to share their light to the world. But then he elaborated in an interesting way:

3rd Nephi 18:24 Therefore, hold up your light that it may shine unto the world. Behold I am the light which ye shall hold up‚Äîthat which ye have seen me do. Behold ye see that I have prayed unto the Father, and ye all have witnessed.

The Lord is their light. He is our light. He is the light we hold up to the world and let shine. He is our light that we let shine.
The pronouns here are impactful by their implication:

He assumes we have light
He assumes we have Him as our light
He invites us to share the light we possess
The light we possess is His light
But it is ours. And it is his. Our light is His light. His light is our light.

‚ÄúLet your light so shine before men that they may see your good works‚Ä¶‚Äù. Read in this new way: obtain the Lord as your light. Then shine His light before men.

title: 1 Nephi 14 - Convincing unto Peace
text:
The Lord gives unto us according to our desires:

For the time cometh, saith the Lamb of God, that I will work a great and a marvelous work among the children of men; a work which shall be everlasting, either on the one hand or on the other‚Äîeither to the convincing of them unto peace and life eternal, or unto the deliverance of them to the hardness of their hearts and the blindness of their minds unto their being brought down into captivity, and also into destruction, both temporally and spiritually, according to the captivity of the devil, of which I have spoken. 1 Nephi 14.7

Remember that He cannot take away our agency. So he doesn‚Äôt come to judge us or cast us to lots of good or evil.
People self select. They choose for themselves in their own life.
And this is the marvelous work: to be convinced of peace.
Am I ‚Äúconvince‚Äù of peace as stated above? Do I recognize that the peaceful way is always the best way through?



Convince me unto peace, please!


No, it says ‚Äúconvincing of them unto peace‚Äù, meaning that convincing them of Jesus, which leads to peace. But the sentiment is the same: that living a life of peace is the one I want.

title: Three Little Pigs
text:
first glance
Yes this is a book review about ‚ÄúThe Three Little Pigs‚Äù.
The first pig is lazy. So he builds his house of straw.
The second is lazy too. So he builds his house of sticks.
Then the third is the smart one who builds his house of bricks.
But the first two brothers just make fun of the mason. Why waste your time?!? We‚Äôre having fun!
So the wolf comes and blows down the houses of the lazy brothers. They run and hide in brick brother‚Äôs house.
Moral of the story: be lazy but have a great, well prepared brother!

title: Three Little Pigs
text:
not quite
I‚Äôve always been bothered by this as I read to my kids. But I‚Äôve recently changed my opinion. Because im very much the first and second brother. We all are.
Were inadequate. Maybe we‚Äôre not smart enough to know how to create bricks and such. Maybe we don‚Äôt have enough resources and the straw is the best we can do. And maybe we hide behind these insecurities by laughing at those who have more.
Maybe we hide behind our insecurity and question God. The Wise One.
See, Christ is our Brick. He‚Äôs the safety. He‚Äôs the home we can run to when the world blows us over. He‚Äôs the Prepared One who was wishing for us to come to him the whole time. The cry of ‚Äúyou‚Äôll be sorry‚Äù by this brother could perhaps be His loving warning of ‚Äúplease be wise. There‚Äôs a wolf out there.‚Äù Yet we don‚Äôt listen. We want to play.
I love the third pig because he lets them in.
Also, the third pig never had to worry about almost getting eaten. Sure, first two enjoyed their fiddle and dance. But they almost died. The third pig is like the non-prodigal son. The one who stayed home and enjoyed the safety of the home the whole time.
Be wise. Be forgiving. And yes, we always have a wise elder Brother who will accept us.

title: 2 Nephi 1 - Shake off the Chains
text:
Scriptures
Keeping the commandments brings blessings:

And he hath said that: Inasmuch as ye shall keep my commandments ye shall prosper in the land; but inasmuch as ye will not keep my commandments ye shall be cut off from my presence. 2 Nephi 1.20

Think about it. Keeping the commandments means being honest, being kind, being respectful, finding a way to help others. Not being lazy. Being productive.
Literally, nobody can prosper without keeping some commandment. Without finding a way to meet someone‚Äôs need.
I also like this verse:

Awake, my sons; put on the armor of righteousness. Shake off the chains with which ye are bound, and come forth out of obscurity, and arise from the dust. 2 Nephi 1.23

It‚Äôs a rallying cry we can all relate to. We are all bound with chains in life. But we don‚Äôt have to be. The call to ‚Äúrise up‚Äù is a call to shake the chains to hold you bound. Arise from the dust!
 # Meaning
It makes me wonder: what are the chains that hold me bound? Perhaps there are limiting beliefs.

title: 1 Nephi 8 - Press Forward Continually
text:
Obtaining the love of Christ is not easy:

I beheld others pressing forward, and they came forth and caught hold of the end of the rod of iron; and they did press forward through the mist of darkness, clinging to the rod of iron, even until they did come forth and partake of the fruit of the tree. 1 Nephi 8.24

Now, He loves us unconditionally. But it is up to us to come to Him.
He constantly invites us to come to Him, and because He gives us agency (Stop trying to change people. Stop it.), we have to choose to follow Him.
This choice isn‚Äôt an easy one. It‚Äôs a difficult one. Some of us get tired and let go. Or we get distracted by all there is around us. Whatever the case - God‚Äôs love for us is constant. It‚Äôs there. It‚Äôs available. It‚Äôs at the tree. It‚Äôs felt through meaningful prayer (The Power of Habitual Prayer). It‚Äôs felt through studying His words. It‚Äôs by building a relationship that we come to Him. It‚Äôs hard work, but it‚Äôs the way we experience the delicious fruit.



The tree of life is also the tree of light. Always there

title: Christmas celebrates a Living Christ
text:
Away in a manger.



Old news
Elder Neil Anderson‚Äôs invitation here is worth listening to. It‚Äôs an invitation to ponder the reality of the birth of our Savior. It‚Äôs rather simple, but it evokes a profound question we should all consider.


How wonderful it is to celebrate the birth of our Savior and Redeemer. Jesus Christ is the central figure of all human history.I know He lives. I know He was born. I know He has been resurrected. I know He is our Savior and Redeemer. And with you I rejoice in this beautiful‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/YDQpIzgk0n

‚Äî Neil L. Andersen (@AndersenNeilL) December 17, 2023




Did He come?
Nothing Elder Anderson shares here is new. It‚Äôs rather repetitive. Same old story. Same-old old-guy telling me to believe in a Jesus.
If you consider the most currently interesting things in this world, Artificial Intelligence, some may tell you that there exists a future utopia where we‚Äôre supported by infinitely intelligent digital agents who can solve complex world problems and bring us to‚Ä¶utopia.
Ok. We‚Äôve also heard this before. The Tower of Babel tried to approximate heaven, and now humanity is trying to approximate Godlike intelligence.
The void of Christ in one‚Äôs life produces a desire to create Christ. A savior. Something to literally save us from our woes.


i think AI is going to be the greatest force for economic empowerment and a lot of people getting rich we have ever seen

‚Äî Sam Altman (@sama) February 13, 2023


Let‚Äôs be real. I‚Äôm a tech optimist. I say bring it on. But I‚Äôm also a Christian. In my view, the most important question isn‚Äôt ‚Äúwhat will AGI do to/for humanity?‚Äù Instead, the most important question is ‚Äúwas Jesus Christ the promised messiah?‚Äù
If Christ came, and was indeed the prophesied Christ, then all of life‚Äôs ultimate questions are already answered.

Why are we here? To die and be resurrected to live again.
Where did we come from? The same place He came from: the presence of God.
Who are we? We are sons and daughters of God worth saving.

Yes, the questions are already answered: it doesn‚Äôt matter what happens with AI. Because the end is known: the Lord will come again.
Let us treasure this time to reflect on a Savior who already came. Who lives. Who loves us beyond mortal (or AI) comprehension.


What can we do?
Let‚Äôs take a moment, perhaps an hour, to consider the miracle of Christmas:


As Christmas approaches, I realize that some may have concerns and perhaps some anxiety about the future. There may be a lot of ‚Äúnoise‚Äù in your life: more or less constant engagement online without downtime, without time to be quiet and reflect and think, without time to look‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/4rqS2F6No9

‚Äî D. Todd Christofferson (@ChristoffDTodd) December 15, 2023

title: 1 Nephi 3 - Dreamed a Dream
text:
A great quote leading up to MLK Jr day:

Behold I have dreamed a dream 1 Nephi 3.2

Lehi dreamed many dreams. It got him in trouble with his boys, as Laman and Lemuel ‚Äúdid murmur in many things against their father, because he was a visionary man‚Äù (1 Nephi 2.11).
Lehi‚Äôs wife, Sariah, also murmured against him, ‚Äúshe also had complained against my father, telling him that he was a visionary man; saying: Behold thou hast led us forth from the land of our inheritance, and my sons are no more, and we perish in the wilderness.‚Äù (1 Nephi 5.2)
Lehi‚Äôs response to this is great:

I know that I am a visionary man; for if I had not seen the things of God in a vision I should not have known the goodness of God, but had tarried at Jerusalem, and had perished with my brethren. But behold, I have obtained a land of promise, in the which things I do rejoice; yea, and I know that the Lord will deliver my sons out of the hands of Laban, and bring them down again unto us in the wilderness. 1 Nephi 5.4‚Äì5

This response teaches me a few things:

when people struggle, they can complain against a good thing and make it a bad thing. ‚ÄúWhy do you always have to be such a goodie two shoes?‚Äù
The response is ‚Äúif I weren‚Äôt such a goodie two shoes I‚Äôd be miserable‚Äù. Helps remind people of the value of their own biases.

Complaining is a natural part of life. Just be careful what you complain about.

title: The Miracles of Christ
text:
I‚Äôm reading the Book of Mormon this year with the Come Follow Me (by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints) curriculum. I hope you enjoy as I write something I learn each day.
I‚Äôll tag things ‚Äúscripture of the day‚Äù for any one-scripture thoughts. If it‚Äôs related to the Come Follow Me theme, l‚Äôll add a tag.

Miracles of Christ
This scripture caught me eye:

For behold, the time cometh, and is not far distant, that with power, the Lord Omnipotent who reigneth, who was, and is from all eternity to all eternity, shall come down from heaven among the children of men, and shall dwell in a tabernacle of clay, and shall go forth amongst men, working mighty miracles, such as healing the sick, raising the dead, causing the lame to walk, the blind to receive their sight, and the deaf to hear, and curing all manner of diseases. Mosiah 3.5




Christ healing all who come unto him


I have seen miracles in my life. I‚Äôve also seen collateral-miracles, which is the miracle that happens when you‚Äôre expecting one thing but another thing happens instead.
I‚Äôve seen someone healed from a Priesthood blessing. I‚Äôve seen someone healed from depression. I‚Äôve seen someone healed from doubt and disbelief. I‚Äôve felt the power of the Holy Ghost in my life.
I‚Äôve also seen people not healed, left to the struggles we all face, and yet miracles abound.
So what is a miracle? Is it an outcome? No.¬†It‚Äôs the process of seeing how an event can be changed by God for the benefit of an individual. Occasionally, there are supernatural changes in the natural course of things.
If any of these things sounds fanciful to those not of my Church, it‚Äôs actually a lot more simple and plain than it sounds. Because ‚Äúthe Lord was not in the wind: and after the wind an earthquake; but the Lord was not in the earthquake: And after the earthquake a fire; but the Lord was not in the fire: and after the fire a still small voice.‚Äù (1 Kings 19.11‚Äì12) For me, seeing a miracle of Christ is perceiving the hand by how he operates.
Some have a hard time reading the Old Testament because how can a God who brought fire from heaven, parted the seas, gave manna from heaven also be a God who doesn‚Äôt do those things today?
I‚Äôd argue the miracles of Christ have risen to the point where he works according to our knowledge and insight. I believe in a Christ who is the source of all truth, and who teaches truth (even scientific) to everyone, regardless of their belief system. Matthew 5.45
And so, the miracles of God today are happening within science. Within tech. He doesn‚Äôt have to heal us by God‚Äôs power if he gave us medicine to do the same.
He also doesn‚Äôt show his miracles the same way. The people of the Old Testament were simple. They needed signs. But signs aren‚Äôt faith, and I believe these days before His second coming are days of greater faith. Days where we‚Äôll have fewer signs.

Therefore, blessed are they who humble themselves without being compelled to be humble; or rather, in other words, blessed is he that believeth in the word of God, and is baptized without stubbornness of heart, yea, without being brought to know the word, or even compelled to know, before they will believe. Yea, there are many who do say: If thou wilt show unto us a sign from heaven, then we shall know of a surety; then we shall believe. 18 Now I ask, is this faith? Behold, I say unto you, Nay; for if a man knoweth a thing he hath no cause to believe, for he knoweth it. Alma 32.16‚Äì18
